Travel_History_Entries.Activities: Attended a family gathering, visited tribal health clinic for routine check-up
Underwent advanced imaging and specialist consultation at Sanford Bemidji Medical Center
Visited Sanford Roger Maris Cancer Center for second opinion and treatment options
Underwent liver biopsy and initial cancer staging at University of Minnesota Medical Center

Travel_History_Narrative.History of Travel Narrative: Patient's recent travel history is primarily for medical purposes related to his hepatitis C and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). He has made multiple trips to larger medical centers for diagnosis, staging, and treatment consultations. In September 2023, he traveled to Minneapolis for a liver biopsy and initial cancer staging at the University of Minnesota Medical Center. In December 2023, he visited Fargo, North Dakota for a second opinion at the Sanford Roger Maris Cancer Center. More recently, in March 2024, he went to Bemidji for advanced imaging and specialist consultation at Sanford Bemidji Medical Center. His most recent travel in May 2024 was to the White Earth Reservation, where he combined a family visit with a routine check-up at the tribal health clinic. These travels indicate the patient's engagement with both specialized urban medical centers and local tribal healthcare facilities for his HCC management, reflecting the complex care needs associated with his condition and the limited specialized healthcare resources in his immediate rural area.

Encounter_Details.Discharge Disposition: Discharged to home or self care with palliative care

Practitioner_Documents.Past Medical History: Patient has a long-standing history of hepatitis C, diagnosed in 1995 following routine screening. He underwent interferon-based therapy in 2000 but failed to achieve sustained virologic response. In 2023, he was diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) as a complication of his chronic hepatitis C infection. Other relevant medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 2015), alcohol use disorder (in remission since 2020), and chronic pain syndrome. He has a history of depression, exacerbated by his cancer diagnosis. The patient also has a history of hypertension and obesity.
Practitioner_Documents.Review of Systems: General: Reports significant fatigue, unintentional weight loss of 15 kg over the past 3 months, and night sweats. Denies fever or chills. HEENT: Denies headaches, vision changes, or hearing problems. Notes yellowing of eyes. Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or palpitations. Reports mild shortness of breath with exertion. Respiratory: Denies cough or wheezing. Gastrointestinal: Complains of severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and early satiety. Reports dark urine and clay-colored stools. Genitourinary: Denies dysuria or hematuria. Notes decreased urine output. Musculoskeletal: Reports general weakness and muscle wasting. Skin: Notes yellowing of skin and easy bruising. Neurological: Denies seizures or loss of consciousness. Reports occasional confusion and difficulty concentrating. Psychiatric: Acknowledges feelings of sadness and hopelessness related to his diagnosis.
Practitioner_Documents.History of Present Illness: Mr. Cloudman726 is a 58-year-old American Indian male with a history of hepatitis C and hepatocellular carcinoma who presents with worsening abdominal pain and weakness. The patient was diagnosed with HCC in September 2023 following surveillance imaging for his chronic hepatitis C. At the time of diagnosis, he was found to have a 7 cm mass in the right lobe of the liver with evidence of portal vein invasion. He underwent transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) in October 2023 with initial response, but follow-up imaging in March 2024 showed disease progression with new lesions. He was started on sorafenib in April 2024 but experienced significant side effects including hand-foot syndrome and diarrhea, leading to dose reduction. Despite this, his most recent imaging from June 2024 shows continued disease progression with development of ascites. Over the past month, he has experienced increasing right upper quadrant pain, which he describes as a constant, dull ache with intermittent sharp exacerbations. The pain is rated 8/10 and is only partially relieved by his current pain medication regimen. He also reports worsening fatigue, anorexia, and unintentional weight loss of about 5 kg in the last month. He has developed worsening jaundice and abdominal distension over the past two weeks. The patient expresses understanding of his poor prognosis and wishes to focus on comfort and quality of life.
Practitioner_Documents.Plan of Treatment: 1. Palliative Care Consultation: Initiate palliative care services to address symptom management and provide psychosocial support. 2. Pain Management: Increase dose of long-acting opioid (morphine ER) and provide breakthrough medication (morphine IR) as needed. Consider adding gabapentin for neuropathic pain component. 3. Ascites Management: Perform therapeutic paracentesis for symptomatic relief. Start spironolactone and furosemide for ongoing management. 4. Nutrition: Consult dietitian for nutritional support recommendations. Consider appetite stimulants if appropriate. 5. Psychosocial Support: Arrange for social work and spiritual care visits. Offer referral to support groups for patients with advanced cancer. 6. Advance Care Planning: Discuss and document patient's wishes regarding code status, artificial nutrition, and preferred setting for end-of-life care. 7. Home Health Services: Arrange for home health nursing and personal care assistance. 8. Follow-up: Schedule outpatient follow-up with oncology in 2 weeks to reassess disease status and symptom control. 9. Patient Education: Provide education on disease progression, management of symptoms, and when to seek urgent medical attention. 10. Discontinue sorafenib given disease progression and focus on comfort care.
Practitioner_Documents.Vaccine Credential Patient Assertion: Patient reports receiving hepatitis B vaccination series in 2000 after hepatitis C diagnosis. Confirms annual influenza vaccinations, with the most recent in October 2023. States he received COVID-19 primary series and one booster in 2022. Unsure about pneumococcal vaccination status. Declines to provide information about other vaccinations.

Diagnosis_Entries.Diagnosis: Cirrhosis of liver due to hepatitis C

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: CT scan, abdomen and pelvis, with contrast
Procedure_Entries.Details: To assess progression of hepatocellular carcinoma and evaluate ascites
Therapeutic paracentesis to relieve abdominal distension and discomfort due to ascites
To evaluate for esophageal varices and assess for any upper GI bleeding

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: Insertion of tunneled central venous catheter
Procedure_Entries.Details: Placement of central line for long-term IV access for palliative care
To assess the degree of liver fibrosis and cirrhosis
Previous palliative treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma
Initial diagnostic biopsy for hepatocellular carcinoma

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: Insertion of implantable pump and intrathecal or epidural catheter
Procedure_Entries.Details: Planned for intrathecal pain management as part of palliative care

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: Destruction of liver lesion(s), radiofrequency ablation
Procedure_Entries.Details: Previous palliative treatment for smaller hepatocellular carcinoma lesions

Procedure_Entries.Procedure Description: MRI, abdomen, without and with contrast
Procedure_Entries.Details: Follow-up imaging to assess disease progression and treatment response

Medication_Entries.Response Details: Disease progression despite treatment, significant side effects
Partial pain relief, dose increase required
Some reduction in ascites, but not complete resolution
Improved urine output, some reduction in edema
Some improvement in mood, but ongoing situational depression
Temporary improvement in serum albumin levels
Recently started, efficacy not yet determined

Case_Summary.Summary: This is a fictional representation of healthcare data intended for interoperability testing and solution development. The data are entirely fictitious and do not represent a real person or a real clinical scenario. A 58-year-old American Indian male with chronic hepatitis C since 1995 developed hepatocellular carcinoma in September 2023. Despite treatments including TACE and sorafenib, his disease progressed. By July 2024, he presented with severe abdominal pain, weakness, and ascites. Lab results showed elevated liver enzymes, bilirubin, and decreased albumin. The patient is now receiving palliative care, focusing on pain management and symptom control, with a poor prognosis due to advanced liver disease and cancer progression.
